unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking of flying within India, eh? Let me tell you, choosing the right airline can make or break your trip! It’s not just about getting from point A to point B, it's about the experience, *yaar*! You don't want to start your Goa vacation stressed out because of a delayed flight, right?
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking of flying within India, eh? Let me tell you, choosing the right airline can make or break your trip! It's not just about getting from point A to point B, it's about the experience, yaar! You don't want to start your Goa vacation stressed out because of a delayed flight, right?

unnormalised: Now, I've flown almost all of them at least once. SpiceJet is often the cheapest, like ₹3500 for a Delhi-Mumbai flight if you book well in advance (say, 2 months?). But, you know, you get what you pay for. I've heard they sometimes have delays and, ahem, *budget* snacks. Nothing against a good *samosa*, but I prefer something a bit more substantial on a 2-hour flight.
normalised: Now, I've flown almost all of them at least once. SpiceJet is often the cheapest, like rupee three thousand five hundred for a Delhi-Mumbai flight if you book well in advance (say, two months?). But, you know, you get what you pay for. I've heard they sometimes have delays and, ahem, budget snacks. Nothing against a good samosa, but I prefer something a bit more substantial on a two hour flight.

unnormalised: IndiGo is usually my go-to. They're generally on time, their planes are reasonably clean, and they have a decent selection of meals you can pre-book. Plus, they’ve got flights everywhere, it seems! Last year I used them to travel from Kolkata to Guwahati and the flight was on time. Paid around ₹4800 for the one-way trip.
normalised: IndiGo is usually my go-to. They're generally on time, their planes are reasonably clean, and they have a decent selection of meals you can pre-book. Plus, they've got flights everywhere, it seems! Last year I used them to travel from Kolkata to Guwahati and the flight was on time. Paid around rupee four thousand eight hundred for the one-way trip.

unnormalised: Air India, our beloved *maharaja* (well, sort of!), has been trying to up their game since the Tata takeover. They’re definitely making improvements, but still sometimes a bit... unpredictable. However, they're often the only ones flying direct to some of the smaller cities, so sometimes you have no choice! Like, if you're going to Patna, you might find Air India is your only option and can cost around Rs. 6000.

unnormalised: Then there's Vistara. Ah, Vistara! If you want a bit of luxury (relatively speaking, of course – we're still talking domestic flights in India!), Vistara is the way to go. They have more legroom, better meals, and generally a more pleasant experience. Their prices reflect that though; expect to pay at least Rs. 7500 for that Mumbai-Delhi flight.

They have more legroom, better meals, and generally a more pleasant experience. Their prices reflect that though; expect to pay at least rupee seven thousand five hundred for that Mumbai-Delhi flight.

unnormalised: Akasa Air is the new kid on the block. I’ve only flown with them once, from Bangalore to Chennai. The aircrafts were new and clean and the staff was also polite. The flight was also on time. The cost for the trip was Rs. 3800.
normalised: Akasa Air is the new kid on the block. I've only flown with them once, from Bangalore to Chennai. The aircrafts were new and clean and the staff was also polite. The flight was also on time. The cost for the trip was rupee three thousand eight hundred.

unnormalised: And don't forget to check for deals! All these airlines have sales running all the time. Sign up for their email lists, and you'll get bombarded with notifications about discounted fares, especially during off-season travel (like, say, right after Diwali). You can often snag a real bargain if you're flexible with your dates. Like, I saw a Delhi to Goa flight for ₹2999 last month during monsoon!

You can often snag a real bargain if you're flexible with your dates. Like, I saw a Delhi to Goa flight for rupee two thousand nine hundred and ninety nine last month during monsoon!

unnormalised: Always double-check the baggage allowance too! They keep changing the rules. And if you're carrying anything fragile (like, say, a traditional Tanjore painting you picked up in Chennai), make sure you pack it carefully. Airlines aren't always the gentlest with your luggage. Also, remember to web check-in 48 hrs before your flight!

And if you're carrying anything fragile (like, say, a traditional Tanjore painting you picked up in Chennai), make sure you pack it carefully. Airlines aren't always the gentlest with your luggage. Also, remember to web check-in forty eight hours before your flight!

unnormalised: So, do your research, compare prices (use those online travel aggregators!), and read the reviews. There's no one-size-fits-all answer. What works for me might not work for you, depending on your budget, your priorities, and where you're going.

unnormalised: Happy travels, and *jai ho*! May your flights be on time, your baggage arrive safely, and your chai be hot! Don’t forget to carry your Aadhaar card, just in case the airline asks for it.
